thread.title: Three takeaways on Rob Portman's stance on foreign trade, job creation
thread.title_full: Three takeaways on Rob Portman's stance on foreign trade, job creation | cleveland.com

author: Jeremy Pelzer, Northeast Ohio Media Group
title: Three takeaways on Rob Portman's stance on foreign trade, job creation
text:
COLUMBUS, Ohio â€” The current U.S. unemployment level is "really disappointing," U.S. Sen. Rob Portman said Friday, and addressing the problem will take job training, less red tape, and improved foreign trade.
Portman made the remarks during an Ohio State University forum on business and innovation. He appeared with Whirlpool CEO Jeff Fettig and other prominent business leaders in the state.
The Cincinnati-area Republican will face a re-election challenge next year from either former Gov. Ted Strickland or Cincinnati City Councilman PG Sittenfeld, both Democrats.
Here are three takeaways from Portman's remark:the event:
1. Currency protections
Portman said U.S. negotiators should do more to prevent other countries from intentionally manipulating the exchange rate of their currencies to gain a trade advantage.
The White House announced Monday that negotiations have concluded on a Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal with 11 Pacific Rim nations. Portman said legislators earlier this year urged negotiators to make currency manipulation a "principal negotiating objective," but the negotiators failed to do so in the proposed trade deal.
"I'd like to put teeth in it, to make it something where currency manipulation is a discussion in trade negotiations," Portman said. "When a country intentionally manipulates currency, it's almost like adding a tariff to their products and reducing the tariff here. Think about it that way. It's not fair."
Portman, who served as U.S. Trade Representative under President George W. Bush, said perhaps every other person who served in that position disagrees with him.
But Portman is supported by many lawmakers from the Midwest and automobile industry officials who worry that Asian countries can keep the price of American-made vehicles artificially high.
2. Ohio's unemployment rate
Portman said September unemployment numbers were "really disappointing.
"The president talks a lot about it, saying, 'We're out of the woods, everything's going well.' It's not," Portman said.
Ohio's unemployment rate dropped slightly last month to 5.6 percent . While that figure is better than the national unemployment rate and is nearly 2 points lower than Ohio's rate in September 2014, Ohio's job growth trailed the national average for the 23 rd consecutive month.
Portman noted that the unemployment rate does not factor in the number of people who have stopped looking for work. About 10 percent of eligible workers are unemployed, he said.
"In effect, we have double-digit unemployment now," he said.
3. Solutions
Portman said job openings exist, but many of them require skilled workers. Ohio, he said, needs to make sure that its workers have the training needed to secure high-paying jobs.
"If companies do not have a skilled workforce here in Ohio, they will go elsewhere," Portman said.
The senator also noted that he's pushing legislation that would require studies of federal economic development programs to see whether they're working or not.
